awd_titl_txt: Improving Undergraduate Scientific Explanations: Exploring the Role of Data Literacy Skills in Scientific Reasoning
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by investigating how teaching undergraduate students to interpret data and apply scientific reasoning can improve their scientific explanations. To this end, the project aims to develop strategic, easy-to-implement approaches to enhance students’ data literacy skills. Students will be guided through a sequence of steps to help them recognize and describe patterns in data.  Additional steps will guide them to use such data patterns as evidence for making conclusions about the phenomena under investigation.  These teaching strategies will be tested in introductory oceanography courses, using data sets from the NSF-funded Ocean Observatories Initiative (OII). By leveraging the community of educators associated with OII, the results of this work will be directly shared with people who teach similar oceanography courses.   As a result, the project anticipates wide adoption of the strategies it finds to be most effective for undergraduate oceanography students. The results of the project are also expected to be applicable across science disciplines and might be used to enhance a broad range of undergraduate courses. Consequently, the project plans to provide online access to the materials and data sets it develops, so that they can be easily adopted or adapted by other educators.

This project is centered on improving undergraduate STEM education by building students’ data literacy and reasoning skills and, ultimately, enhancing their ability to construct scientifically accurate explanations. The project aims to investigate how a modified explanation framework could influence the development of undergraduate students' scientific explanation skills and seeks to identify the specific challenges undergraduate students experience when constructing scientific explanations. Specifically, this project will link two cognitive realms, scientific reasoning and data literacy, to develop more effective instructional strategies for improving undergraduate students’ science literacy. The project will follow a convergent, multiphase mixed methods research approach, which will include a pilot study to collect both quantitative and qualitative data that will inform the later stages of the project. Guided by their instructors, students will use pedagogically appropriate and adjustable data visualizations from the OOI Data Explorations project, together with complementary static (e.g., paper) graphical representations. The design and implementation of instructional strategies used in this project will be evaluated to consider the professional development needs of future instructors seeking to implement the interventions.  Dissemination plans have been designed to ensure that effective strategies are shared broadly with science instructors, learning scientists, and other educational researchers. This proposal was submitted in response to the “Dear Colleague Letter: Stimulating Participation from Institutions New to the Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Education and Human Resources Program" (NSF 20-034).  The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
To complete this project the research team developed an instructional sequence designed to improve students’ data literacy while they analyze data sets related to phenomena studied in introductory oceanography classes using web-based interactive visualizations (graphs and maps). These first steps guide students to: read the graphs and maps properly and make connections to the content they are learning; describe patterns and trends in the data; and compare patterns and trends across multiple data sets. With this early step of examining and describing data sets intentionally, students were then guided to use the science background information provided in the class to draw a conclusion about the data sets, and then explain that conclusion connecting appropriate and sufficient evidence from the data provided to the relevant science concepts learned. They completed their conclusion and explanation steps using a process advocated in the K-12 Next Generation Science Standards, adapted for an introductory college course. This “claim-evidence-reasoning” structure to a scientific explanation breaks down the components of the work in ways that our students found useful. We adapted it for college learning and added the “data description” step at the beginning. We created and tested a set of lessons and interactive data visualizations using authentic data sets produced by various science research projects that were relevant for topics studied in our classes. To evaluate student work, we adapted an evaluation tool related to scientific explanations available for K-12 educational settings for college learning experiences and by adding the “data description” step.

Our study included seven sections of students who completed our instructional strategies (“intervention”); a total of 191 students were involved. Their work produced during and after our intervention was compared to similar work from 184 students in five comparison sections who completed the same scientific explanations as exam questions but who did not experience our intervention (“comparison” sections). Results indicate that students who participated in the full intervention performed significantly better on exam questions that required them to complete data descriptions and to write scientific explanations. The intervention students also performed significantly better on an ocean content pre/post-test designed for the classes involved. From student interviews early and late in the semester in intervention sections, we heard that the students saw the value of the instructional experience for: learning science content more deeply as opposed to just memorizing information; composing evidence-supported explanations for conclusions they make by figuring out the appropriate components that need to be included and then putting those pieces together for a complete explanation; and applying in other contexts outside the classroom and in daily life. We have shared the resources and results at numerous conferences and workshops and will be doing so in three or more professional research papers submitted to science education journals as well as to earth science specific journals.

Undergraduate science courses for non-STEM students can be the last carefully guided formal science education opportunity for many people. The tested instructional strategy offers college educators an option that can help develop scientific reasoning and data literacy skills and complements other effective teaching strategies available. The general structure of the instructional sequence can be used in any discipline where students use data to make sense of the content addressed. The improved scientific reasoning and data literacy skills will enhance the abilities of citizens to make daily decisions and useful contributions to our data-driven society.
